p: Global warming has increased interest in potential sources of biofuels in the last decade [ 13] as alternatives to petroleum-derived fuels (i.e., [ 14– 15]). The development and production of biofuels is a particularly important issue in states with a strong dependence on petroleum imports. Biofuels are mainly produced from energy crops; biodiesel is produced from oilseed species, such as soybean ( Glycine max, Fabaceae), rapeseed ( Brassica napus, B. rapa, and B. juncea), sunflower ( Helianthus annuus, Asteraceae), flax ( Linum usitatissimum, Linaceae), and the African oil palm ( Elaeis guineensis, Palmaceae) [ 16]. The cultivation of these species, however, has important environmental costs (see [ 16– 21]).
